text: well Timbuktu is just this most amazing
other-worldly kind of place we were
blown away by it we first arrived even
the name is mythical Timbuktu the idea
replaced at such a very long way from
anywhere else it used to be on the
tourist trail for the more adventurous
travelers it's hardly surprising when
you see it but that all stopped a few
years ago when Islamic extremists took
over the city and impose Sharia law and
then they try to destroy priceless
manuscripts that the ancient Touareg
families have kept for generations in
centuries the Imam the main mosque
showed us some of his dug out of a
cardboard box he'd hidden them from the
jihadists two years two and a half years
since they left but still he hasn't got
them on the shelves yet it's hard to
imagine now but this place was once
famous all over the world as being a
center of learning maths theology and
Islam and all these beautiful crumbling
manuscripts prove it
I hope you like the drone footage by the
way one of the guys from the UN brought
one along with him
thanks very much Olivier he got the most
amazing stuff for us kids by the masks
hadn't seen one before and they've got
way too excited the reason we came here
was to meet some of the peacekeepers
from the UN that the blue helmets they
call them there are about 40,000 in Mali
from around 50 different countries many
stationed in the most dangerous bit
which is here in northern Mali right on
the edge of the Sahara Desert
after a year running Timbuktu and other
cities up here the French troops
actually forced jihadists out and the UN
is now trying to keep them out although
we didn't see many there's still a load
of French troops around lots of Special
Forces targeting groups of extremists
it's really complicated trying to work
out who's who there are all these Tuareg
separatist groups who fought each other
for years and now have a peace deal
going then mixing all the bandits people
traffickers and drug smugglers in this
wide-open space and it's way too hard to
explain an alphabet soup of French
acronyms you'd imagine it's all desert
up here but the Niger River is Timbuktu
lifeline and trading hub we went out on
loads of different UN patrols with
different countries some soldiers some
police this one was by a little port was
with troops from Burkina Faso they've
given more here than anyone else about
1600 troops most of Maurice mer as the
UN mission is called come from countries
in the region but still the jihadists
target them in the same way they do
Westerners its classic counterinsurgency
tactics because a big threat is roadside
bombs or suicide bombers like it was in
Iraq or Afghanistan so they go out and
try and win people over showing them
around keeping an eye on things and
trying to get info the guys from the
Bangladeshi Navy were great after a
curried egg breakfast they took us out
on a river patrol a bit tricky landing a
drone on a boat but it stayed dry and we
used quite a bit of the footage in our
news story it's a great perspective
makes you realize how big the spaces are
here it's really tough to try and keep
an eye on what's going on in the place
like this
even going out at night I'm glad to say
there were no attacks after being told
by an intelligence guy afterwards that
there's an al-qaeda-linked group
operating just outside Timbuktu we were
even happier to have been wearing the
body armor it was a full moon and a good
place to sum up this idea of it being
quite familiar this whole operation the
way it's being run what the UN is doing
here is very reminiscent of what British
troops were doing in Afghanistan it's
about coming out and showing sign of
force about winning the hearts and minds
of local people and also defending
against roadside bombs and suicide
attacks but yet this is supposed to be a
peacekeeping operation Mali is the most
dangerous place to be a UN peacekeeper
around 60 have died around 200 injured
and I suppose the question is why why
are so many UN troops in Majerle of all
places well when you think about it
Timbuktu is not that far away anymore
just one country Algeria and the
Mediterranean Sea lie between here in
Europe this part of the Sahara is firmly
on the cocaine trail the new route from
South America and migrants pass through
here to some call it the new frontline
against is like extremists and this
mission is certainly a big investment
and by the looks of things they're in it
for the long haul we may well be hearing
more from Mali
